affirmative

aff -- helipads -- nfls finals

1ac -- inherency


Since the Status-of-Forces agreement with Japan in the mid-20th century, the US and Japan have been close allies and partners on the international stage --- in this day and age as threats continue to mount, maintaining our relationships with critical allies like Japan is a cornerstone of wise foreign policy --- unfortunately, one particular issue has come up posing a rift in the entire alliance ---

Currently, V-22 Ospreys, or US Marine Corps’ helicopters, are deployed in US territory, an air base in Okinawa, Japan, known as Futenma
Lance Corporal Benjamin Pryer stationed in Japan, published in 2012 (Lance Corporal Benjamin Pryer, Marine Corps Air Station Iwakuni, “Arrival Marks Significant Step,” Okinawa Marine, News, July 27, 2012, http://community.marines.mil/unit/mcbjapan/Documents/OkiMar/120727.pdf)
The Osprey’s capabilities will significantly …. at MCAS Futenma during the summer of 2013.

Dangerously, the Futenma location is massively unpopular with Japan and is single-handedly threatening to tear apart the entire alliance --- we need a different location
Chester Dawson, senior correspondent for the Wall Street Journal in Tokyo, wrote in 2012 (Chester Dawson, senior correspondent for the Wall Street Journal based in Tokyo, Japan, M.A. in East Asian studies from Harvard University, “Japan Balks at Deployment of Aircraft,” July 20, 2012, The Wall Street Journal, Online)
TOKYO—Three days before a long-awaited …. to the current U.S. schedule, it would hurt the U.S.-Japan alliance," Mr. Maehara told reporters on Thursday.

1ac adv -- alliance


Our second contention is the first advantage, the alliance advantage ---

Despite the fact that many Japanese favor the alliance, the Osprey issue has begun to unravel support and the alliance is at risk
Jonathan Volkle, Lieutenan in the US Navy, published in 2012 (Jonathan M. Volkle, Lieutenant, United States Navy, B.A., University of Massachusetts, “Comparative Study of Base Community Relations in Japan,” Naval Postgraduate School, Master of Arts in Security Studies, December 2012, pg. 28)
Even more recently, the decision to … already seem to be at an all-time high.

Even on top of the opposition, the US is currently forcing Japan to pay for the heliport in Futenma
The Asahi Shimbun, a Japanese news source, published in 2012 (Asahi Shimbun, news source, “New Demands Emerge in Revised U.S. Military Realignment,” February 7, 2012, http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/politics/AJ201202070060)
Yet, U.S. officials are also asking … of relocating the heliport functions.

As expected, forcing them to “foot the bill” has exacerbated tears in relations
Terashima Jitsuro, president of Tama University, wrote in 2010 (Terashima Jitsuro, president of Tama University, as well as president of the Mitsui Global Strategic Studies Institute and chairman of the Japan Research Institute, “The US-Japan Alliance Must Evolve: The Futenma Flip-Flop, the Hatoyama Failure and the Future,” Foreign Policy in Focus, August 20, 2010, http://www.fpif.org/articles/the_us-japan_alliance_must_evolve)
The revelation that the US military …. a loss to them. The key word they have put forward in support of maintaining the status quo is "deterrence."

Furthermore, the helicopters in Futenma will continue to spark an avalanche of opposition --- the US will be kicked out of all other bases as a result which jeopardizes the entire security relationship --- relocating helipads is necessary to avoid backlash
The Japan Times published in 2012 (Japan Times, News Source, “Rethink Osprey Deployment,” October 4, 2012, http://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2012/10/04/ editorials/rethink-osprey-deployment/#.UWNc1ZNthnU)
But the point is that Okinawans will not … the air station’s functions to outside their prefecture.

Relocating to avoid backlash is necessary to prevent a collapse of vital financial cooperation --- the Japanese alliance is critical to fix the global economy
Agents France Press published in 2009(7/23, Lexis)
US President Barack Obama's nominee to be …. and trade between the United States and Japan," he said.

External to the economy, the alliance is also critical to solve a host of transnational threats
Robert Gates, former U.S. Secretary of Defense, explained 2011 – “U.S.-Japan Alliance a Cornerstone of Asian Security”, Speech to Keio University, 1-14, http://www.defense.gov/speeches/speech.aspx?speechid=1529)
Over the course of its history, the U.S.-Japan … working together – and they also almost always require leadership and involvement by key regional players such as the U.S. and Japan.

Nuclear terrorism is feasible and would trigger full scale nuclear conflict
Patrick Speice at the College of William and Mary explains in 2006 (Patrick, JD Candidate, 47 Wm and Mary L. Rev. 1427, February, Lexis)
Terrorist groups could acquire a nuclear weapon by a …. conflicts will draw in the United States and escalate to the use of nuclear weapons.

Cyber-attacks are also likely and feasible --- it would risk nuclear war
Journalist Ron Rosenbaum wrote in 2008 (Ron Rosenbaum, American journalist and author, “A Real Nuclear Option for the Nominees,” Slate, May 9, 2008, http://www.slate.com/articles/life/the_spectator/2008/05/a_real_nuclear_option_for_the_nominees.single.html)
According to a recent paper by Blair (whose account …. weapons on hair-trigger is clear."

1ac adv -- deterrence


Because the Futenma location for Ospreys carries with it so much opposition, the Futenma location is not sustainable and will eventually be flat out rejected by Japan --- this would pose grave dangers for our Osprey helicopter presence currently deployed

Unfortunately, Ospreys are the critical way the US deters conflict with China over the Senkaku islands, a territory that China has been eyeing ever so closely ---
Watanabe Tsuneo, Senior Fellow at the Tokyo Foundation, wrote in 2012 (Watanabe Tsuneo, Director, Policy Research, Senior Fellow, The Tokyo Foundation, Adjunct Fellow, Center for Strategic and International Studies, Senior Fellow, Okinawa Peace Assistance Center, former senior fellow at the Mitsui Global Strategic Studies Institute in Tokyo, “Between Okinawa and the Senkakus: Charting a Third Way on Japanese Security,” The Tokyo Foundation, November 22, 2012, http://www.tokyofoundation.org/en/articles/2012/between-okinawa-and-senkaku)
From the standpoint of international security, … the US bases becomes more hostile.

A break in deterrence over the Senkaku islands risks massive escalation and warfare --- several factors make this conflict incredibly probable and likely to escalate ---
Michael Klare, a professor at Hampshire college, wrote in 2013 (Michael Klare, professor of peace and world security studies at Hampshire College, “The Next War”, 1/23/13, http://www.realclearworld.com/articles/2013/01/23/the_next_war_100500.html)
Lurking just behind the Iranian imbroglio, however, is a … should play a more vigorous and assertive role in the region and the world.

Furthermore, because of opposition, Osprey operations become ineffective and slowed which hampers effective deterrence
The Yomiuri Shimbun writes in 2012 (Yomiuri Shimbun, “Osprey Deployment Will Promote Both Deterrence and Safety,” September 20, 2012, http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-303059779/editorial-osprey-deployment-promote.html)
Reasonable compromise by U.S. Negotiations between …. more understanding so Osprey operations will go smoothly.

In addition to Chinese aggression, backlash to Futenma risks collapsing vital deterrence enhancements that diffuse the North Korean nuclear conundrum
Jeffrey Hays, a resident of Saga, Japan, published in 2013 (Jeffrey Hays, teacher, writer living in Saga, Japan, “Criticism of the U.S. Military in Okinawa and Japan: Drunk Soldiers, Rapes, Noise, Ospreys, and Futenma,” last updated January 2013, http://factsanddetails.com/japan.php?itemid=1865&catid=22&subcatid=148)
The Yomiuri Shimbun reported: “The Osprey can …. event of a crisis on the Korean Peninsula.

With recent developments and despite promises of peace, North Korea might miscalculate absent effective deterrence which would escalate and could include nuclear weapons
Steven Metz, Professor at the Strategic Studies Institute, wrote in March 2013 (Steven, Chairman – Regional Strategy and Planning Department and Research Professor of National Security – Strategic Studies Institute, “Strategic Horizons: Thinking the Unthinkable on a Second Korean War”, World Politics Review, 2013, http://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/12786/strategic-horizons-thinking-the-unthinkable-on-a-second-korean-war)
Today, North Korea is the most …. Stranger things have happened in statecraft.

1ac -- plan text


The United States Marine Corps should substantially increase its Iwakuni Air Station helipad transportation infrastructure investment in the United States.

1ac -- solvency


Our final contention is solvency ---

Here’s one last piece of evidence that describes our plan’s solvency --- helipad functions in US Marine Corps Iwakuni, away from Futenma, enables Ospreys to land and be deployed elsewhere --- this approach is a palatable alternative to the Japanese and prevents a fracturing of our alliance
Ryukyu Shimpo, a journalist in Okiwana, published in 1999 (“DAILY SUMMARY OF JAPANESE PRESS”, 8-11, http://www.usc.edu/libraries/archives/dsjp/summaries/1999/August/Sm990811.htm)
The Okinawa prefectural government, which has …. area of Tomakomai in Hokkaido or to Iwakuni Marine Air Station.

aff -- depots -- nfls

1ac adv -- nasa


The first contention is the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, or NASA, advantage ---

Currently, NASA is developing the Space Launch System, a heavy launch vehicle that will dictate future space launch policy. However, this path is extremely expensive and is beginning to devour NASA’s budget affecting other NASA programs --- Mark Matthews of the Washington Bureauwrote in 2011 (Mark K. Matthews, Washington Bureau, “NASA's Smaller Programs Could Be at Risk,” Orlando Sentinel, August 30, 2011, http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-08-30/news/os-nasa-budget-worries-20110830_1_james-webb-space-telescope-keith-cowing-internal-nasa-documents)
The cost of NASA's …carry fewer instruments.

Even more wastefully, launches themselves will be too expensive and would use up the entire annual budget for just a single launch
John Strickland, the founder of the National Space Society Chapters Assembly, wrote in 2011 (John Strickland, founder of the National Space Society Chapters Assembly, Senior Programmer/Analyst for the State of Texas, “The SLS: Too Expensive for Exploration?” The Space Review, November 28, 2011, http://www.thespacereview.com/article/1979/1)
The crucial fiscal … intervals between launches.

This draining of NASA’s budget affects overall diplomacy and US credibility --- rebalancing NASA’s budget is critical to support broader diplomatic engagement with other nations ---
Vincent Sabathier, senior associate with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, wrote in 2008 (Vincent G. Sabathier, senior associate with the CSIS Technology and Public Policy Program, G. Ryan Faith, research analyst for the Space Foundation, “Smart Power Through Space,” Center for Strategic and International Studies, 2008, http://csis.org/files/media/csis/pubs/080220_smart_power_through_space.pdf)
In much the … American per day.

Furthermore, NASA’s ability to enable cooperation helps reduce the likelihood of war --- it is a critical factor of international partnership
Dr. John Logsdon, Director at George Washington University, published in 2007 (Dr. John M. Logsdon - Director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, Research professor of Political Science and International Affairs at George Washington University, “Human Space Flight and National Power,” High Frontier, March 2007, Volume 3 Number 2, pg. http://www.gwu.edu/~spi/assets/docs/DrLogsdon_HF_Article.pdf)
This question has … in other arenas.

External to diplomacy, if NASA’s budget continues to be sucked up by the SLS, earth science programs will be cut --- dangerously, continued earth science monitoring plays a key role in aiding solutions to environmental problems such as climate change, biodiversity loss and ozone depletion
Timothy Killeen,Director of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, wrote in 2005 (Timothy L. Killeen, Director, National Center for Atmospheric Research, “NASA Earth Science,” CQ Congressional Testimony, April 28, 2005, Lexis)
NASA Earth science … simultaneous multiple stresses.

1ac adv -- space launch industry


The second advantage is the space launch industry ---

First, even with the development of the Space Launch System, the space launch industry still suffers from a lack of investment leaving it on the brink of collapse --- large scale federal investment is critical
Frank Slazer, the Vice President of the Space Systems Division, published in 2012 (Frank Slazer, Vice President, Space Systems Division, Aerospace Industries Association, “Perspectives on NASA’s Strategic Direction,” The Space Review, September 10, 2012, http://www.thespacereview.com/article/2154/1)
As you are …the industrial base.

Unfortunately, as the industry declines, so too will overall US technological innovation --- America will be technologically bankrupt and powerless
The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, published in 2012 (American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, “Assuring the Viability of the US Aerospace and Defense Industrial Base,” 2012, https://www.aiaa.org/2012KeyIssues/)
The aerospace and … when they arise.

External to technological innovation, the space industrial base is key to effective cyber-deterrence. Only continual technological development will continue to protect the US.
National Aerospace Week, wrote in 2010 “Aerospace and Defense: The Strength to Lift America,” September 18, 2010, http://www.nationalaerospaceweek.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/whitepaper.pdf)
The beginning of ….combating cyber attack.

Cyber-attacks are extremely likely in the status quo --- it’s where we’re vulnerable and other countries have the technology --- it would risk nuclear war
Journalist Ron Rosenbaum wrote in 2008 (Ron Rosenbaum, American journalist and author, “A Real Nuclear Option for the Nominees,” Slate, May 9, 2008, http://www.slate.com/articles/life/the_spectator/2008/05/a_real_nuclear_option_for_the_nominees.single.html)
According to a …hair-trigger is clear."

Furthermore, preventing a collapse of the launch industrial base is critical to maintain the bedrock of the economy
National Aerospace Week published in 2010 (September 18, National Aerospace Week
“Aerospace and Defense: The Strength to Lift America,” http://www.nationalaerospaceweek.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/whitepaper.pdf)
As the U.S. … of younger employees.

In addition to job loss and economic downturn, decline in the economy could even risk war as the US and other states are forced to intervene ---
Mathew Harris, Counselor of the U.S. National Intelligence Council, wrote in 2009 (Mathew Harris, Counselor of the U.S. National Intelligence Council, Jennifer Burrows, Member of the NIC’s Long Range Analysis Unit, “Revisiting the Future: Geopolitical Effects of the Financial Crisis,” The Washington Quarterly, http://www.twq.com/09april/docs/09apr_Burrows.pdf)
Of course, the ….dog-eat-dog world.

1ac -- plan text


Thus, the United States federal government should substantially increase its propellant depot investment in the United States.

1ac -- inherency


Propellant depots are not being funded by NASA. The Space Launch System currently dominates their budget.
Journalist DougMessier published in 2011 (Doug Messier, “Debate Rages Over Fuel Depots vs. Heavy Lift Vehicles,” Parabolic Arc, November 7, 2011, http://www.parabolicarc.com/2011/11/07/debate-rages-over-fuel-depots-vs-heavy-lift-vehicles/)
The debate is … fuel depot work.

1ac -- solvency


Our final contention is solvency

All the technology for propellant depots already exists and has already been tested.
Jeff Foust, Ph.D. in planetary science from MIT, wrote in 2008 (Jeff Foust, editor and publisher of The Space Review, aerospace analyst, PhD in planetary sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, “Propellant Depots: An Idea Whose Time Has (Almost) Come,” The Space Review, May 12, 2008, http://www.thespacereview.com/article/1127/1)
“The key thing … propellants in zero-g.

Increasing investment in orbital propellant depots solves the NASA advantage. It expands the budget and frees up critical resources while preventing long term cuts and providing short-term savings
Andrew Gasser, the President of TPIS, was published in the Space Review in 2011 (Andrew Gasser, currently the President and National Coordinator TPIS, “Propellant Depots: The Fiscally Responsible and Feasible Alternative to SLS,” The Space Review, October 24, 2011, http://www.thespacereview.com/article/1955/1)
It is fair to … be bumped up.

The plan jumpstarts the space launch industry. Currently, programs are failing and draining remaining capital.

The word “its” means the investment belongs solely to the US
GEGT, 5 (Glossary of English Grammar Terms, 2005, http://www.usingenglish.com/glossary/possessive-pronoun.html)
Mine, yours, his, hers, its, ours, theirs are the possessive pronouns used to substitute a noun and to show possession or ownership. EG. This is your disk and that's mine. (Mine substitutes the word disk and shows that it belongs to me.)

The words “transportation investment” mean federal funding
Warner, 11 – US Senator who introduced this bill into the Senate (introduced by Mark Warner and Mark Kirk, “S. 1968: A bill to require the Secretary of Transportation to establish a pilot program to increase accountability with respect to outcomes of transportation investments, and for other purposes,” December 8, 2011, http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/s1968/text)

Kornegay 09 (H. Thomas Kornegay, Executive Director, The Port of Houston Authority, “Dredging up a Disaster: Declining Federal Maintenance of Nation’s Ports,” World Energy Source, Vol. 8, No. 4, 2009, http://www.worldenergysource.com/articles/text/kornegay_WE_v8n4.cfm)
Houston clinched a deal with the federal government by offering to share the cost of dredging a deepwater port. Known as the Houston Plan, it set a precedent for local cost sharing in federal projects that is still used today. U.S. Representative Tom Ball, who developed this brilliant idea, said: "Prior to Houston’s offer, no substantial contribution had ever been made by local interests to secure the adoption of their projects, and no project has since been adopted by the national government without promise of local contributions and assurance that the waterfront would not be privately controlled."

1nc -- doctrinal shift counterplan


Text: The United States federal government should not construct transportation infrastructure for homeporting a CVN at Naval Station Mayport but instead should undertake an assessment of carrier vulnerabilities through evaluation of potential risks such as terrorism, sabotage, infiltration, denial and subterfuge, weather complications, and homeport or logistics hub attacks at current CVN homeports. If sufficient risk of vulnerabilities in CVN homeports are found, then and only then should the United States federal government support and guarantee the development and deployment of all necessary components of the ForceNet program, the AirSea battle doctrine, Draco Unmanned Surface Vehicle Systems, undersea drones to prevent Iran from closing the Strait of Hormuz, and surface combatants and submarines, with the support that would have otherwise supported the CVN operational mission including current and future homeporting of CVNs. We’ll clarify.

New military evaluations to expose carrier vulnerabilities from homeporting attacks and subsequent doctrinal shift is key and solves
Patch 10 (Commander John Patch, US Navy, “Fortress at Sea? The Carrier Invulnerability Myth,” US Naval Institute, Proceedings Magazine, January 2010, http://www.usni.org/magazines/proceedings/2010-01/fortress-sea-carrier-invulnerability-myth)

1nc -- nms counterplan


The Chair of the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the United States should issue a National Military Strategy, and corresponding National Security Space Strategy and Joint Strategic Capabilities Plan that prioritizes the dredging, infrastructure and wharf improvements, and construction of CVN nuclear propulsion plant maintenance facilities at Naval Station Mayport for the purpose of homeporting a CVN as necessary to achieve the national security goals of the United States.

1nc -- adv. counterplan

--- develop and deploy the High Speed Container Delivery Systems and hybrid airships
--- implement and enforce comprehensive Joint Operational Access Concept including the substantial increase of development and deployment of relevant capacities as outlined in the Eleni evidence below
--- increase its development and utilization of Maritime Domain Awareness capabilities
